prompt: machines are thought to work in two ways : On a high pulse rate of 90 - 130 Hz ( the normal method of use ) , the electrical impulses
watermarked_text: machines are thought to work in two ways : On a high pulse rate of 90 - 130 Hz ( the normal method of use ), the electrical impulses are delivered to the area of pain, where they act to increase the transmission of nerve impulses. These impulses stimulate the nerve fibers to release neurotransmitting substances that help to relieve the pain. This is thought to be the primary mechanism of action for TENS. On a low pulse rate of 2-10 Hz, TENS is thought to act by inhibiting pain transmission in the spinal cord. This is known as the gate control theory of pain. It involves the stimulation of large diameter myelinated fibers in the skin which compete for synaptic space in the spinal cord with the pain fibers, thus reducing the transmission of pain. This mechanism is useful for chronic pain and can be used to reduce the intensity of pain or stop it altogether. It is also used to improve circulation, reduce muscle spasm, and promote relaxation of muscles. TENS can be used for a variety of chronic pain conditions, including arthritis, low back pain, fibromyalgia, dental pain, and carpal tunnel syndrome
unwatermarked_text:
machines are thought to work in two ways : On a high pulse rate of 90 - 130 Hz ( the normal method of use ), the electrical impulses stimulate the muscles and nerves.
There are various types & sizes of TENS machines available. The most common type is a battery - powered unit. Some have multiple channels which allow for the use of several pairs of electrodes simultaneously, whilst others have single channel devices.
The electrodes are usually made of a conductive rubber or gel-filled material and are placed on the skin in the area to be treated. The machine is adjusted so that the intensity of the electrical pulses is comfortable but not painful. The duration of treatment depends on the condition being treated, but typically 15 - 30 minutes is sufficient. Treatments can be carried out daily for as long as needed.
While TENS is generally safe and well - tolerated when used as directed, there are some contraindications. These include :
1. Implants such as pacemakers, ICDs, or neurostimulators.
2. Severe infections or inflammatory skin conditions.
3. Presence of implanted electrodes or metal fragments near the treatment site
natural_text: generated by the TENS machine interfere with and block pain messages sent to the brain . This is due to the gate control theory of pain . This proposes that there is a gate mechanism in the brain and spinal cord nerves ( the central nervous system ) . When the gate is open , pain messages get through to the brain and we feel pain . When the gate is closed , these pain messages are blocked and we do not feel pain . TENS machines are thought to stimulate certain non - pain - carrying nerves and close the gate . In effect , the brain is busy dealing with the messages it receives quickly from the TENS machine , rather than the slower ( more painful ) pain signals that the body is receiving from elsewhere . It explains why , if you injure yourself , rubbing that area can temporarily reduce the pain . When the machine is set on a low pulse rate ( 2 - 5 Hz ) it stimulates the body to make its own pain - easing chemicals called endorphins . These act a bit like morphine to block pain signals .,

Main article: Developmental coordination disorder
Developmental coordination disorder (DCD), previously known as minimal coordination disorder or clumsy child syndrome, is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by difficulties with motor functions and coordination, which can impair the ability to move and perform everyday tasks. Some children with DCD also have associated conditions such as dyspraxia. Symptoms can include difficulties with balance, motor planning, trailing or rubbing when walking, awkwardness and clumsiness, delayed motor milestones, and problems with visual-motor integration. Delays in motor milestones : Your child may have difficulty with movement skills such as crawling, walking, or even tying their shoes.

Difficulty with writing and fine motor skills : Your child likely has poor handwriting and may struggle with activities like drawing, coloring, or using scissors.

Dyspraxia may affect everyday life skills in many ways , both because of the motor difficulties and because of difficulties with organisation . Children may have problems with self - care , organising themselves and their belongings , and in engaging with groups of other children . They may also have problems with organising their thoughts , which can affect organised mental tasks like mental maths , learning material for examinations , and planning timetables . Dyspraxia can cause social and emotional difficulties as well as problems with self - organisation .,

New connections form as our nerve endings find their way to receptors or muscles, and our brain learns to interpret and respond to the sensory information that these connections provide.
Learning a new skill requires perseverance and practice. Every time we perform the skill, connections between our nerves are strengthened, making it easier to perform the action the next time. With enough practice, our nerve connections become very good at this particular task, and the skill becomes a habit or automatic response. This is why it often takes a long time to learn complex skills like playing a musical instrument or riding a bicycle. Sometimes, our nervous system may not form the connections we need to learn a skill quickly or easily. This can be due to various factors, including genes, injury, or lack of practice. to predict the outcome of the next general election. The truth is that unless the question is asked in exactly the same way, different surveys will give different results. And if the question is asked in different ways, the only sure result is that the opinions expressed in the papers will not be exactly the same.
There are many ways in which a question of this kind can be put. The standard method, used by Gallup and others, is to ask which party the electors would like to see in power after the next election. There is a simpler form of the question, commonly asked in preferential elections, which asks people to choose between the names of individual leaders, without specifying parties. The latter method can give an indication of the personality factor in elections, which is always difficult to measure accurately.
A question asked in relation to a hypothetical election also involves an element of uncertainty. People's preferences sometimes change in the course of a campaign, and what they say now may not be what they will think next spring. Furthermore, it has been observed that some people vote in hypothetical elections who would not vote in a real one.

erythematous telangiectasia

broken capillaries
Broken capillaries on the face appear as small, thin lines or webs of red, purple, or blue color on the skin. These capillaries are dilated and become visible due to the thinness of the skin on the face.

pustules

This may be because of what is called a ' new mutation ' ( a ' de novo mutation ' ) . A new mutation is a mutation ( or a fault ) in a gene that is present for the first time in one family member . It can happen because of : A fault in the genetic material in either the egg or sperm of one of the affected person 's parents ; or A fault in the genetic material of the egg fertilised when the egg and sperm meet ( the embryo ) . It is not clear what causes this fault ( mutation ) to suddenly occur for the first time . Also , if an individual in your family who is carrying the faulty HD gene dies before their symptoms develop ( and therefore before HD is diagnosed ) , relatives will not be aware of this family history . natural_text: most commonly after a fractured skull caused by a head injury . The fractured skull bone can cause separation of the dura mater from the inside of the skull and can cause damage to a blood vessel ( usually an artery ) . The damaged blood vessel causes blood to leak and collect in the potential epidural space between the skull and the dura mater . This build - up of blood can cause the pressure inside the head to rise . This can put pressure on the brain and cause injury to the brain if it is not treated quickly . Typically , an extradural haematoma is caused by a severe head injury - for example , in a road traffic accident . The blood usually collects in the epidural space soon after a head injury and symptoms of an extradural haematoma are usually noticed quickly . So , most extradural haematomas are ' acute ' injuries . Occasionally , bleeding can occur more slowly and an extradural haematoma may cause few symptoms ( and so not be noticed ) until some days after a head injury . The rest of this leaflet just discusses intracranial extradural haematoma .,

natural_text: , surgery is generally needed to treat a large intracranial extradural haematoma . This is usually carried out by a neurosurgeon and involves removal of the haematoma . Most commonly , surgery either involves making ' burr holes ' in the skull or an operation called a craniotomy . Burr holes are small holes that are drilled through the skull over the area where the haematoma has formed . They allow the blood to be removed , or ' sucked out ' , through the holes . Stitches or staples are then used to close the burr holes . A craniotomy is a procedure in which a portion of the skull is removed so that the brain and meninges are exposed . It can relieve any raised pressure inside the skull and also means that the clotting blood in the extradural space can be removed . The section of skull that was removed is then replaced and fixed back in place , re - attaching the outer protective lining that covers the brain ( the dura mater ) to the skull bone . Close follow - up is needed after the operation , usually in an intensive care unit .,

What is the Nucleus Cochlear Implant System?
The Nucleus Cochlear Implant System, developed by Cochlear Ltd., is a well-known bone conduction hearing implant that uses bone conduction technology to transmit sound vibrations to the inner ear. This system is designed for individuals with conductive or mixed hearing loss who can't benefit from traditional air conduction hearing aids.
Instead of air conduction, which transmits sound through the air to the eardrums, the Nucleus Cochlear Implant System bypasses the damaged parts of the ear and sends sound vibrations directly to the inner ear through the bones. This allows the user to hear sounds more clearly and naturally.

through the skin to an internal implant inside the cochlea. This implant allows the hearing nerve to be stimulated despite the fact that the cochlear cells are damaged. The cochlear implant receives audio signals from a sound processor and converts them into electrical signals.
A cochlear implant is a small, multi-component device that includes:
  1. A sound processor : This is typically a digital device that captures sound from the environment and converts it into electrical signals.
  2. A transmitting coil : This coil is worn behind the ear and transmits the electrical signals from the sound processor to the implant.
  3. A receiver/stimulator : This component is surgically implanted within the skull, usually behind the ear. It receives the electrical signals and sends them directly to the auditory nerve, bypassing the damaged cochlear cells.
  4. Electrodes : These fine wires are placed within the cochlea and deliver the electrical signals to specific points, which stimulate the auditory nerve.
  5. Battery : Some implants have a built-in battery, while others require an external power source.

natural_text: Antibodies are small proteins that circulate in the bloodstream . They are part of the body 's defence ( immune ) system and are sometimes called immunoglobulins . They are made by B lymphocytes - a type of white blood cell . The IgA gets to the kidneys in the bloodstream and then causes scarring and inflammation in the kidney . The scarring and inflammation are very small and can only be seen with a microscope . The glomeruli are damaged by deposits of IgA. IgA nephropathy does not usually run in families , so you need not worry about passing it on to your children . The cause of IgA nephropathy is not completely understood . IgA is produced by glands around the throat and bowel to fight off infection . IgA is normally two antibody molecules stuck together . In IgA nephropathy , these molecules appear to get joined up in longer chains . As these travel around in the blood and pass through the kidney they get stuck in the filters ( glomeruli ) in the kidney . The trapped IgA then causes an inflammatory reaction . It is not known why these IgA chains develop .,

A common cause of PID is from a sexually transmitted infection ( STI ) . The germs ( bacteria ) are passed on when you have sex . Chlamydia and gonorrhoea are the most commonly found causes of PID . A mixture of chlamydia plus gonorrhoea sometimes occurs . Another type of bacterium called Mycoplasma genitalium is also a common cause . Sometimes the bacteria can be in the neck of the womb for some time without causing symptoms . When they travel into the womb you become unwell . This is why you might develop PID weeks or months after having sex with an infected person . Some cases of PID are not due to an STI . The vagina normally contains many different bacteria . These are usually harmless and are not passed on by sexual contact . However , these bacteria sometimes cause PID . This is more of a risk after having a baby , or after a procedure such as inserting an intrauterine contraceptive device ( coil ) .,

Rheumatic heart disease is a general term which means any heart problem which develops after having rheumatic fever. Most, but not all, people who experience rheumatic fever develop some form of heart disease. Rheumatic fever commonly affects the hearts valves, particularly the mitral valve and the aortic valve. Over time, the valve becomes thick and stiff, causing it to be less able to open and close properly. As a result, blood can leak backward, leading to problems like heart failure, irregular heartbeats, and blood clots. The long-term effects of rheumatic fever on the heart can be serious, potentially leading to heart failure or other complications. Early recognition and treatment of rheumatic heart disease are crucial to prevent further damage to the heart and its valves. Management of the condition includes medication to reduce inflammation and antibiotics to prevent recurrent infection. In some cases, surgical intervention, such as valve repair or replacement, may be necessary to restore proper heart function. The prognosis for people with rheumatic heart diseases varies depending on the severity of the condition, but with proper care and management

What causes scoliosis in children?
The exact cause of scoliosis in children is often unknown, and it is considered an idiopathic condition, meaning it arises without a known cause. However, it is thought that a combination of genetic and environmental factors can contribute to the development of idiopathic scoliosis.

Scoliosis affects children and adolescents, and it is more common in females. The condition usually develops during the growth period, which is why it's most commonly seen between the ages of 10 and 16. Signs of scoliosis may include uneven shoulders or hips, a curved spine, or a change in the way your child stands or walks.

Mitral regurgitation is sometimes called mitral insufficiency or mitral incompetence . In mitral regurgitation the valve does not close properly . This causes blood to leak back ( regurgitate ) into the left atrium when the left ventricle squeezes ( contracts ) . Basically , the more open the valve remains , the more blood regurgitates and the more severe the problem . This is also called floppy mitral valve . In this condition the valve is slightly deformed and bulges back into the left atrium when the ventricle contracts . This can let a small amount of blood leak back into the left atrium . As many as 1 in 20 people have some degree of mitral valve prolapse . It most commonly occurs in young women . It usually causes no symptoms , as the amount of blood that leaks back is often slight . The cause of most cases of floppy valve is unknown . It sometimes occurs with connective tissue disorders such as Marfan 's syndrome .,

In the case of an allergy, the immune system reacts to normally harmless substances like pollen or certain foods, seeing them as foreign invaders and producing antibodies against them. These antibodies then trigger the release of chemicals that cause symptoms such as sneezing, itching, or rashes.
When the immune system is properly functioning, it helps us stay healthy by fighting off infections and foreign substances. In systemic sclerosis , the immune system damages the connective tissue cells , which are found in many parts of the body . Your connective tissue supports , binds or separates other tissues and organs within your body and can also be a kind of packing tissue in your body . So , systemic sclerosis is also classed as a connective tissue disease . It is not known what triggers the immune system to cause systemic sclerosis . There is probably an inherited tendency to develop it . It is more common in people who have a family member with systemic sclerosis . It may be triggered by certain germs ( such as viruses ) , medicines , street drugs and chemicals . A number of different influences seem to be involved . What is known is that cells called fibroblasts are affected by the immune system in some way and make too much of a protein called collagen . The collagen gets deposited in skin , blood vessels and organs . This causes scarring and thickening ( fibrosis ) . Blood vessels are also damaged .,

What disorder involves excessive concern with body appearance and preoccupation with defects that may be slight or imagined?
Body Dysmorphic disorder ( BDD) is a psychiatric disorder characterized by an excessive and persistent concern with an imagined or slight defect in one's physical appearance. People with this disorder may focus on a physical defect that others cannot see or have a mild physical flaw that they find distressing. The concern about the defect can lead to significant impairment in social and occupational functioning. Treatment for BDD typically involves a combination of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and pharmacotherapy. In CBT, individuals learn to recognize and challenge negative thoughts about their appearance and develop healthier coping strategies. Medications such as antidepressants, particularly selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), may be prescribed to help reduce symptoms of anxiety and depression associated with BDD. It

There are similarities between these two conditions in terms of obsessive thoughts and compulsive behaviors. It is likely that a combination of genetic, neurobiological, psychological, and social factors contribute to the development of this condition.
Complications [ edit ]
BDD can be a significant source of distress, impairment in daily functioning, and suicide risk. Individuals with BDD may avoid social interactions or situations where they cannot conceal their appearance concerns. This can lead to isolation, loneliness, and a poor quality of life. Some individuals may also engage in behaviors intended to hide or change their appearance, which can be time-consuming, expensive, and potentially harmful.

Is diabetes a hormone imbalance? Why or why not?
No, diabetes is not a hormone imbalance. Diabetes is a condition where the body has trouble regulating blood sugar levels. While hormones like insulin and glucagon are involved in regulating blood sugar, diabetes is not caused by an imbalance of hormones alone. In type 1 diabetes, the pancreas does not produce enough insulin, which is a hormone that helps regulate blood sugar levels. In type 2 diabetes, the body becomes resistant to insulin or doesn't produce enough insulin. So, diabetes is more about a problem with insulin production or the body's response to it, rather than an overall hormone imbalance
unwatermarked_text: . A hormone is a chemical which is made in one part of the body but passes into the bloodstream and has effects on other parts of the body. It is a substance secreted by a gland or other specialized tissue that has the capacity to influence the function or development of other glands, tissues, or organs. There are many hormones in our body, and each one has its own specific function. They help regulate various bodily processes such as growth and development, metabolism, sexual function, and even our mood and behavior. For example, insulin is a hormone that helps regulate blood sugar levels, while estrogen and progesterone help regulate the menstrual cycle. Hormones play a vital role in maintaining our overall health and well-being. natural_text: Cells in the outer part of the adrenals ( adrenal cortex ) make the hormones cortisol and aldosterone . The amount of cortisol that is made is controlled by another hormone called adrenocorticotrophic hormone ( ACTH ) . ACTH is made in a small gland that lies just under the brain ( the pituitary gland ) . This in turn is stimulated by another hormone which is produced by another part of the brain , called the hypothalamus . ACTH passes into the bloodstream , is carried to the adrenal glands and stimulates the adrenal glands to make cortisol . Cortisol is a hormone that is vital for health . It has many functions which include : Helping to regulate blood pressure . Helping to regulate the immune system . Helping to balance the effect of insulin in regulating the blood sugar level . Helping the body to respond to stress . Aldosterone helps to regulate salts in the blood and helps to control blood pressure . Cells in the inner part of the adrenals ( adrenal medulla ) make the hormones adrenaline ( epinephrine ) and noradrenaline ( norepinephrine ) . These have various actions throughout the body .,

Inherited conditions : Some inherited conditions, such as familial adrenoleukodystrophy

natural_text: Lymph glands ( also called lymph nodes ) occur throughout the body . They are normally pea - sized . They are a major part of the body 's defence ( immune ) system . During an infection , lymph glands swell and become painful while the immune system fights off infecting germs . They go back to normal after the infection is over . Most people are familiar with lymph glands in the neck that can swell when you have a sore throat or tonsillitis . In a similar way , it is the lymph glands in the tummy , next to the gut ( intestine ) , that swell during a bout of mesenteric adenitis . ( See separate leaflet called Swollen Lymph Glands for more about lymph glands . ) Probably , a germ ( infection ) triggers the inflammation and swelling in the lymph glands . Most cases are probably due to a viral infection . Less often , it may be a bacterial infection that is the cause - for example , a bacterial infection in the intestine . The inflamed glands then cause pain , tenderness and a high temperature ( fever ) .,

The exact cause of Rett's syndrome is unknown. It is not believed to be a hereditary disorder. In some cases, girls with the condition have been found to have a de novo mutation in the MECP2 gene, which suggests that it may be a genetic disorder caused by new mutations. However, other cases do not show this mutation, so there may be other causes.
Some researchers believe that an imbalance of certain neurotransmitters in the brain, such as serotonin and gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), may contribute to some of the symptoms of Rett’s syndrome.
Rett's syndrome was first described by Austrian neurologist Dr. Andrea Rett in 1966. She observed a distinct pattern of developmental regression and movement abnormalities in girls, which led to the recognition of this disorder as a unique medical condition. High blood pressure means that the force of your blood against the walls of your arteries is consistently too high. This increases your risk of health problems such as heart disease, stroke, and kidney disease. It often has no symptoms, hence its nickname the'silent killer'.

If meningitis is suspected, it is important to seek immediate medical attention.
Treatment for bacterial meningitis usually involves administering antibiotics intravenously (through a vein) in hospital. Antiviral medication may be used for viral meningitis. Supportive care, such as fluids and pain relief, may also be given.
Complications of bacterial meningitis can be severe and include hearing loss, vision problems, seizures, intellectual disability, and even death. It is essential to seek medical help as soon as possible if you suspect meningitis to minimize the risk of complications.

Adults may also develop a petechral rash, as well as fever, headache, myalgia and neck stiffness. Severe cases can include seizures and coma.
Meningococcal disease can present with various combinations of these symptoms, and not all people with the infection develop all of them. People who have had the infection before, or who have certain pre-existing medical conditions, may have a reduced symptom profile, or may even be asymptomatic.
Meningococcus can be transmitted between individuals through respiratory droplets from coughing or sneezing, or through direct contact with respiratory secretions. To help you prepare for the scan, you will not be allowed to eat or drink for 8 hours before the test. This will empty your stomach and make it easier to get a clear picture of your liver.

The scan itself takes about 30 to 60 minutes, but the entire process, including preparation and injection of the contrast agent, may take up to 2 hours.

Note : there are various other autoimmune diseases . Most tend to run a persistent ( chronic ) course once the immune system is triggered - for example , rheumatoid arthritis . However , GBS is different in that the disease activity seems to be time - limited . That is , the immune system reacts to a recent infection which can cause nerve damage , but then settles down again . This is why most people with GBS recover fully .,

Food and water – Norovirus can contaminate food and water, particularly if it has come into contact with infected feces. This can occur through contaminated sewage, shellfish, or eating raw or undercooked shellfish.
People – Norovirus can be spread through close contact with people who are infected. This can happen when an infected person vomits near you, or touches food, drinks, or surfaces with contaminated hands. It is also possible for the virus to spread through respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs or sneezes.
Fomites – Norovirus can spread through indirect contact with contaminated surfaces or objects ( fomites ), such as doorknobs, countertops, utensils, or cutting boards. Touching these contaminated surfaces and then touching your face or mouth can allow the virus to enter your body.

There are two different types of diabetes : Type 1 diabetes is the type of diabetes that typically develops in children and young adults . In type 1 diabetes the body stops making insulin and the blood sugar level goes very high . Treatment to control the blood sugar level is with insulin injections and a healthy diet . Type 2 diabetes is the type which occurs mostly in people aged over 40 years but is becoming more common in younger adults and in children . The first - line treatment is diet , weight control and physical activity . If the blood sugar level remains high despite these measures then tablets to reduce the blood sugar level are usually advised . Insulin injections are needed in some cases . A heart murmur is a whooshing or buzzing sound that your doctor may hear when listening to your heart with a stethoscope. Heart murmurs are very common and usually harmless.
A heart murmur is caused by blood flowing through the heart in an abnormal way. It can be due to a variety of conditions, such as a hole in the heart, damaged heart valves, or abnormal blood vessels connecting the heart to the lungs.
Most heart murmurs are not serious and do not require treatment. Your doctor will monitor the murmur and perform tests to determine if it is causing any problems.
In some cases, a heart murmur may be a sign of a more serious heart condition. If your doctor discovers a heart murmur during a physical examination, they may recommend further testing, such as an echocardiogram or electrocardiogram, to evaluate the heart's structure and function.

Acne is a common skin condition characterized by the formation of pimples, whiteheads, blackheads, and occasionally cysts on the skin. It usually occurs during puberty, but can affect individuals of all ages. There are several factors that can contribute to the development of acne, including the overproduction of sebum, the presence of bacteria, clogged pores, and hormonal imbalances. The diagnosis of acne is typically made based on the appearance of the skin and a thorough medical history. Treatment for acne depends on the severity of the condition. You should discuss these techniques with your healthcare provider to determine which one works best for you. Managing breathlessness during physical activity is also important, and your healthcare provider or respiratory therapist can provide guidance on how to pace yourself and plan your activities accordingly. Breathing exercises can be particularly useful during episodes of breathlessness, before and after exercise, and when lying flat. It is important to remember that while these breathing techniques can help relieve breathlessness, they may not eliminate it completely.

This involves using your diaphragm and lower chest muscles to breathe instead of your upper chest and shoulder muscles . Breathe gently and keep your shoulders and upper chest muscles relaxed . Use different comfortable seating and standing positions when you feel breathless . Different positions suit different people but examples include : When standing up , lean from the hips with your forearms resting on something at a comfortable height , such as a chair or kitchen work surface . When standing or walking , put your hands on your hips or in your pockets . When sitting , lean forwards , resting your forearms on your knees , on the arms of a chair , or on a table . natural_text: . Most of the tissue between the atria and ventricles does not conduct the impulse . However , a thin band of conducting fibres called the atrioventricular bundle ( AV bundle ) acts like ' wires ' and carries the impulse from the AV node to the ventricles . The AV bundle splits into two - a right and a left branch . These then split into many tiny fibres ( the Purkinje system ) which conduct the electrical impulse throughout the ventricles . This makes the ventricles contract and pump blood through one - way valves into large arteries : The artery going from the right ventricle ( pulmonary artery ) takes blood to the lungs . The artery going from the left ventricle ( aorta ) takes blood to the rest of the body . The heart then rests for a short time ( diastole ) . Blood coming back to the heart from the large veins fills the atria during diastole : The veins coming into the left atria bring blood from the lungs ( full of oxygen ) . The veins coming into the right atria bring blood from the body ( needing oxygen ) .,
